Authors: Selene Setsuko Nikaido, Jay Alan Raveill
Title:
Mulberry (Morus:Moraceae) hybridization in eastern North
America: morphological and molecular evidence
Keywords:
Morus alba, Morus rubra, Moraceae, hybridization, ITS,
trnL, trnF, intergenic spacer, RFLP
Abstract:
Two species of mulberry (Morus:Moraceae) are found in
eastern North America. Red mulberry (M. rubra) is generally found as a
subcanopy or understory species in native forest while white mulberry
(M. alba) occurs in more open or disturbed locations. Sequencing
chloroplast (trnL-F region) and nuclear (18S-28S ribosomal DNA region)
genes demonstrated genetic separation between the species and revealed
species-specific restriction fragment length polymorphisms within the
intron of trnL and within ITS1 between 18S and 5.8S ribosomal RNA genes.
Possible hybridization between mulberry species was examined at three
locations in west-central Missouri where the habitats of the two species
were in close proximity. Individuals heterozygous for the ITS1
restriction fragment length polymorphic site were confirmed as hybrids.
Hybrid individuals were present at each location and primarily occurred
in the habitat of the chloroplast parent. Morphological comparison
between the parental species was complicated by the high level of
variation within individuals, but was most successful when variation
extremes were measured from samples taken specifically to document the
total morphological variation of that individual. The morphology of the
confirmed hybrids was on average intermediate between the two species
but when separated into two groups by chloroplast parent then the
intermediacy was minimal and hybrids clustered with samples of the
maternal parent.
